For assistance with IPA transcriptions of Kurdish for Wikipedia articles, see Help:IPA/Kurdish.
This article contains IPA phonetic symbols. Without proper rendering support, you may see question marks, boxes, or other symbols instead of Unicode characters. For an introductory guide on IPA symbols, see Help:IPA.

Kurdish phonology is the sound system of the Kurdish language continuum. This article includes the phonology of the three Kurdish dialects in their standard form respectively. Phonological features include the distinction between aspirated and unaspirated voiceless stops and the presence of facultative phonemes.[1][2]

Contents

    • 1.1 Labialization
    • 1.2 Palatalization
    • 1.3 Pharyngealization
    • 1.4 Facultative consonants
  • 2 Vowels

Consonants[edit]

Geographic distribution of Kurdish and Zaza–Gorani[3]
  Northern
  Central
  Southern
  Zazaki
  Gorani
  mixed areas

The consonants are pronounced the same in the three dialects (Northern Kurdish, Central Kurdish and Southern Kurdish), unless noted.

Consonant phonemes[1][4][5]
Labial Dental/
Alveolar 		Palatal Velar Uvular Pharyngeal Glottal
plain velar. plain labial. plain labial. plain labial.
Nasal m n ŋ
Plosive voiceless asp. pʰ tʰ t͡ʃʰ kʰ qʰ
vcls. unasp. p t t͡ʃ k kʷ q qʷ ʔ
voiced b d d͡ʒ ɡ ɡʷ
Fricative voiceless f s sˠ ʃ x xʷ ħ h
voiced v z zˠ ʒ ɣ ɣʷ ʕ
Approximant l ɫ j ɥ w
Rhotic ɾ r
  • /n, t, d/ are laminal denti-alveolar [n̪, t̪, d̪], while /s, z/ are dentalized laminal alveolar [s̪, z̪],[6] pronounced with the blade of the tongue very close to the back of the upper front teeth, with the tip resting behind lower front teeth.
  • Kurdish contrasts plain alveolar /l/ and velarized postalveolar[7] /ɫ/ lateral approximants. Unlike in English, the sounds are separate phonemes rather than allophones.[8]
  • Postvocalic /d/ is lenited to an approximant [ð̞]. This is a regional feature occurring in other Iranian languages as well and called by Windfuhr the "Zagros d".[9]
  • Kurdish has two rhotic sounds; the alveolar flap (/ɾ/) and the alveolar trill (/r/). While the former is alveolar, the latter has an alveo-palatal articulation.[10]
  • According to Hamid (2015), /x, xʷ, ɣ, ɣʷ/ are uvular [χ, χʷ, ʁ, ʁʷ] in Central Kurdish.[11]
  • Northern Kurdish distinguishes between aspirated and unaspirated voiceless stops, which can be aspirated in all positions. Thus /p/ contrasts with /pʰ/, /t/ with /tʰ/, /k/ with /kʰ/, /q/ with /qʰ/, and the affricate /t͡ʃ/ with /t͡ʃʰ/.[2][8][12]
  • Although [ɥ] is considered an allophone of /w/, some phonologists argue that it should be considered a phoneme.[13]
  • Kurdish distinguishes between the plain /s/ and /z/ and the velarized /sˠ/ and /zˠ/. These velarized counterparts are less emphatic than the Semitic emphatic consonants.[14][15]
  • [ɲ] is an allophone of /n/ in Southern Kurdish, occurring in the about 11 to 19 words that have the consonant group ⟨nz⟩. The word yânza is pronounced as [jɑːɲzˠa].[16]

Labialization[edit]

  • Kurdish has labialized counterparts to the velar plosives, the voiceless velar fricative and the uvular stop. Thus /k/ contrasts with /kʷ/, /ɡ/ with /ɡʷ/, /x/ with /xʷ/, and /q/ with /qʷ/.[17] These labialized counterparts do not have any distinct letters or digraph. Examples are the word xulam ('servant') which is pronounced as [xʷɯˈlɑːm], and qoç ('horn') is pronounced as [qʷɨnd͡ʒ].[18]

Palatalization[edit]

  • After /ɫ/, /t/ is palatalized to [tʲ]. An example is the Central Kurdish word gâlta ('joke'), which is pronounced as [gɑːɫˈtʲæ].[8]
  • /k/ and /ɡ/ are strongly palatalized before the front vowels /i/ and /e/ as well as [ɥ], becoming acoustically similar to /t͡ʃ/ and /d͡ʒ/.[2]
  • When preceding /ŋ/, /s, z/ are palatalized to /ʒ/. In the same environment, /ʃ/ also becomes /ʒ/.[19]

Pharyngealization[edit]

  • In some cases, /p, t, k, s, z/ are pharyngealized to [pˤ, tˤ, kˤ, sˤ, zˤ]. For example, the word sed/ṣed is pronounced as [ˈsˤɛd][8][4][20]
  • Furthermore, while [fˤ] and [ɡˤ] are unique to Central Kurdish,[5] Northern Kurdish has [t͡ʃˤ].[21]

Facultative consonants[edit]

  • /ħ/ and /ɣ/ are non-native phonemes that are mostly present in words of Arabic origin. Even though they are usually replaced by /h/ and /x/ respectively, they are facultative. Thus the word heft/ḧeft ('seven' /ˈħɛft/) can be pronounced as either [ˈhɛft] or [ˈħɛft], and xerîb/ẍerîb ('stranger', /ɣɛˈriːb/) as either [xɛˈriːb] or [ɣɛˈriːb].[22]
  • /ʕ/ is only present in words of Arabic and Persian origin and is only present in initial position.[23] An Arabic loanword like "Hasan" would thus be pronounced as /ʕɛˈsɛn/.[24] The phoneme is absent in some Northern and Southern Kurdish dialects.[25]

Vowels[edit]

The vowel inventory differs by dialect, some dialect having more vowel phonemes than others. /iː, ʊ, uː, ɛ, eː, oː, ɑː/ are the only vowel phonemes present in all three Kurdish dialects.

Vowel phonemes[26][27]
  Front Central Back
unrounded rounded unrounded rounded
Close iː ʉ
ɨ		 ɯ ʊ
uː
Close-mid eː øː o
oː
Open-mid ɛ
Open a ɑː

Detailed table[edit]

Letter Phoneme
Northern[28] Central[29] Southern[30][31]
a ɑː a a[32]
â – ɑː ɑː[33]
e ɛ ɛ ɛ
ê eː eː eː
i ɯ ɯ ɨ[34]
î iː iː iː
o oː oː o
ô – – oː
ö – – øː[35]
u ʊ ʊ ʊ[36]
û uː uː uː
ü – – ʉː[37]

Notes[edit]

  • In Central Kurdish, /a/ is realized as [æ], except before /w/ where it becomes mid-centralized to [ə]. For example, the word gawra ('grey' or 'fair-skinned') is pronounced as [ɡəwˈɾæ].[38]
  • /ɯ/ is realized as [ɪ] and [ɨ] in certain environments.[27][39][40]
  • In some words, /ɯ/ and /u/ are realized as [ɨ]. This allophone occurs when ⟨i⟩ is present in a closed syllable that ends with /m/ and in some certain words like dims ('molasses'). The word vedixwim ('I am drinking') is thus pronounced as [vɛdɯˈxʷɨm],[39] while dims is pronounced as [dɨms].[41]

Facultative vowels[edit]

  • /øː/ only exists in Southern Kurdish, represented by ⟨ö⟩. In Northern Kurdish, it is only present facultatively in loan words from Turkish, as it mostly merges with /oː/. The word öks (from Turkish ökse meaning 'clayish mud') is pronounced as either [øːks] or [oːks].[42]
  • 'Short o' ([o]) is not common in Kurdish and exists mostly in loanwords from Turkish like komite, which is pronounced as [komiːˈtɛ].[43]

Glides and diphthongs[edit]

The glides [w], [j], and [ɥ] appear in syllable onsets immediately followed by a full vowel. All combinations except the last three are present in all three Kurdish dialects. If the word used as an example is unique to a dialect, the dialect is mentioned.

Diphthongs[44][45][13]
IPA Spelling Example Word Dialect Group
Northern Central Southern
[əw] aw şaw [ˈʃəw] 'night' (Central Kurdish)
[ɑːw] âw çaw [ˈt͡ʃɑːw] 'eye' (Central Kurdish)
[ɑːj] ây çay [ˈt͡ʃɑːj] 'tea'
[ɛw] ew kew [ˈkɛw] 'partridge'
[ɛj] ey peynja [pɛjˈnʒæ]
[pɛjˈnʒɑː] 		'ladder'
[oːj] oy birôyn [bɯˈɾoːjn] 'let's go' (Central Kurdish)
[uːj] ûy çûy [ˈt͡ʃuːj] 'went' (Central Kurdish)
[ɑːɥ] a da [ˈdɑːɥ] 'ogre' (Southern Kurdish)
[ʉːɥ] ü küa [ˈkʉːɥɑː] 'mountain' (Southern Kurdish)
[ɛɥ] e tela [tɛɥˈlɑː] 'stable' (Southern Kurdish)
